questions.text: At what age does mature pincer grip develops?
questions.solution:
6 months → Drops one object when another is offered

7 months → Transfers object & uni-dextrous approach

9 months → - immature Pincer grasp

12 - 13 months → Casting appear, mouthing disappear, mature grip develops

15 months → Feeds himself with cup, slight spillage

Topic: Pincer grip

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, pagenumber: 135

questions.text: Which of the following disease/s must be suspected when a child has regression of milestones?
questions.solution:
• The hallmark of many degenerative disorders is neurological regression.
  • Loss of only language skills - autism - suspected.
  • Regression of both language and motor milestones → Rett's syndrome.
  • Regression of motor milestones → neuromuscular disease is one of the important differentials.

Topic: Regression of milestones

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition., page number: 158

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy has behavioral problems. His foster mother states that when he is upset, he will have a tantrum, throw toys, and hit anyone near him. He was dismissed from preschool because of concerns for the safety of his classmates. The boy was recently placed in the care of his foster mother who does not know the circumstances leading to his removal from his biological family. She asks about possible contributors to his aggressive behaviors. Which of the following can be a possible explanation?
questions.solution:
• Aggressive behaviors in children have been associated with prenatal exposure to substances including cocaine, alcohol, and tobacco.
  • Aggression is influenced by the interaction between the prefrontal cortex, which can inhibit actions, and the limbic system, where emotional arousal resides.
  • Children who have anxiety may demonstrate reactive aggression when their anxiety is triggered and the child is unable to cope.

Topic: Cocaine

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition., page number: 978

choices.text: As long as you don't fill the tub up too much, and you can hear him, he's fine by himself
Children shouldn't be left alone in the tub until 6 years age
As long as his 8 year old sister is watching him he should be fine
Children are fine in the bathtub as young as age 2 if they have a special bath seat

questions.text: 3-year-old's mother is worried. She asks, "Isn't he old enough to be alone in the bathtub? He likes to play in there for hours!" What is the best advice for her?
questions.solution:
• Children can drown in minimal amounts of water. Not only should tubs and pools be super vised, but 5-gallon buckets should be emptied when toddlers are around and toilets or bathrooms should have locks.
  • Supervisors of bath time should be at least a teenager or adult, as older sib lings can be distracted easily.
  • Bath rings and seats can fall over, leading to drowning. They offer a false sense of security.

Topic: Safety standards

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition., page number: 143

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the emergency department for treatment of a generalized headache. Review of her chart shows that she has been seen over a dozen times in the past 6 months with complaints of headaches, abdominal pain, presyncope, and ethanol intoxication. On examination, her vital signs are normal for her age, and the findings of fundoscopic, cranial nerve, and neurological examinations are normal. Her affect is flat, and she appears disheveled. The findings of the remainder of her examination are normal. Of the following most appropriate next step is?
questions.solution:
• The child exposed to toxic stress may present with any of a variety of physical, cognitive, or psychological symptoms, and thus health care providers must remain on high alert for children in need of interventions.
  • Exposure to violence has a strong link to depressive symptoms and suicidality.
  • The emergency department may be the first or only place to which children undergoing toxic stress present.
  • The combination of symptoms does not fit into any other options.

Topic: Child Psychiatry

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition., page number: 219

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought in for a well child visit to a new caregiver. The child was born at 39 weeks gestation and delivery history is unremarkable. The growth chart shows the weight was initially at the 50th percentile and increased to the 75th percentile by 6 months. It dropped to the 25th percentile at 9 months and is at the 10th percentile now. Length has remained stable at the 50th percentile. What is the most likely explanation for these changes?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis is failure to thrive (FTT) as evidence by dropping at least two major growth percentile lines on the growth chart.
  • The most common causes of failure to thrive are poverty, lack of parental knowledge, and poor feeding behavior.
  • In constitutional growth delay, weight and height decrease near end of infancy, parallel the norm through middle childhood and accelerate towards adolescence ultimately achieving normal adult height.
  • Hypothyroidism or growth hormone deficiency would classically affect height in addition to weight.

Topic: Failure to thrive

Reference: Nelson pediatric symptom based diagnosis, page number. 144

questions.text: A 16-year-old adolescent boy is seen for follow-up after hospital admission for acute onset of abdominal pain, nausea, and hematemesis. His evaluation included an upper endoscopy which revealed acute hemorrhagic erosive gastritis. He has a history of asthma, for which he uses fluticasone and montelukast daily, and a history of headaches, for which frequent use of acetaminophen is reported. In addition, he has a history of alcohol and marijuana use; on the day the symptoms began, he had consumed multiple alcoholic beverages and used marijuana heavily. Which of the following substance is most likely to cause the symptoms?
questions.solution:
As the patient developed GI symptoms post heavy ingestion of alcohol and marijuana, the likely symptom is due to either of the two

Single large ingestion if alcohol leads to acute erosive gastritis


Topic: Alcohol consumption symptoms

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number: 1049 and 1052

questions.text: In normal fine motor development, which of the following should occur first?
questions.solution:
• Children tend to be able to copy a shape 6 months before they can draw it.
  • The usual developmental order of drawing shapes is: line, circle, cross, square, triangle.

Topic: Fine motor development

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number.: 182

questions.text: Which of the following prophylactic vitamin administration has been shown to decrease significantly the risk of bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) development in extremely low birth weight (ELBW) infants?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin A supplementation has found to reduce the risk of bronchopulmonary dysplasia in ELBW infants.

Topic: BPD (Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia)

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number: 2325

questions.text: A patient involved in a motor vehicle accident presents to the emergency department. After the appropriate protocol is initiated, the patient is evaluated for a laceration of a finger. The decision is made to inject epinephrine with bupivacaine prior to primary closure with sutures. Shortly thereafter, pallor of the finger is noted. What should be done immediately?
questions.solution:
• Extravasation of epinephrine is a serious side effect and must be treated immediately.
  • An alpha-adrenergic blocking agent should be administered to oppose the vasoconstriction induced by epinephrine.
  • The infusion should be stopped and gently aspirated without flushing the line.
  • Phentolamine or an alternative antidote may be readministered if the patient remains symptomatic.

Topic: epinephrine

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number:850

questions.text: An 8-week-old male infant is brought to the clinic to evaluate a diaper rash. His growth has been poor and he has had prolonged diarrhea. His mother has tried zinc oxide cream and a topic antifungal medication without improvement. On exam, he is thin and has erythematous, well-defined, scaly plaques with bullae and erosions. The rash is on his cheeks, around his mouth, and in his diaper area. Which of the following is deficient?
questions.solution:
• This infant has acrodermatitis enteropathica from zinc deficiency.
  • Trace elements or minerals are present in low concentrations in the body but necessary for many enzymatic pathways.
  • Zinc is needed to grow, taste and smell, heal wounds, and fight infections.
  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica, a hereditary defect in zinc absorption, causes diarrhea, dermatitis, and alopecia.
  • The eczema-like rash has red, scaling plaques that develop bullae, crusting, and erosions in a U-shaped distribution on the face, perioral, acral, and diaper areas.
  • Effects of copper, iodine and chromium deficiency are given in table below -

Topic: Zinc deficiency

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number:3587

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after drinking an unknown amount of mouthwash. The girl's mother found her with an empty bottle of mouthwash in the bathroom. She is unsure how much had been in the bottle. The girl had 4 episodes of nonbloody, nonbilious vomiting prior to arriving at the emergency department. She has a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 138 beats/min, respiratory rate of 12 breaths/min, and blood pressure of 108/66 mm Hg. She appears lethargic and is poorly responsive to painful stimuli. The remainder of the girl's physical examination findings are unremarkable. Her airway, breathing, and circulation are stabilized. Of the following, the BEST next step in this girl's management is?
questions.solution:
• In addition to beer, wine, and liquor, ethanol is found in a wide variety of household products (eg., mouthwash, cough, and cold medications) that are easily accessible to children of all ages.
  • Ethanol inhibits hepatic gluconeogenesis; children (especially young children) who ingest ethanol can become profoundly hypoglycemic.
  • Alcohol is the substance most widely abused by adolescents. It is important to consider congestion in an older child or adolescent with a suspected intentional ingestion.

Topic: Alcohol

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition., page number: 508

questions.text: A 24-month-old girl is brought to the clinic for a health supervision visit. Her parents ask what technique is most helpful in the toilet training process. The girl is otherwise developmentally appropriate and healthy. Her mother is 39 weeks pregnant. Of the following most appropriate method is?
questions.solution:
• The toilet training child should:
    1. have a safe, comfortable toilet environment, including an accessible toilet or chair at the appropriate size,
    2. use training paints as a transition from diapers to underwear, and
    3. be encouraged and provided positive reinforcement.
  • To avoid toilet training refusal, parents should avoid parent child conflict over toileting, which may be counterproductive and potentially damaging, leading to development of withholding behaviors, chronic constipation, and encopresis.

Topic: Toilet training

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition., page number: 2816

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy was eating a sandwich and fruit at a local playground. His mother was feeding him grapes and milk when he suddenly developed respiratory distress, coughed briefly, then became apneic, pale, and limp. His mother delivered several blows to his back and called for help. An emergency medical services crew was nearby, and they provided abdominal thrusts without success. Just before his arrival in the emergency department, the child became pulseless, and chest compressions and bag-valve mask ventilation were begun. On arrival, the child remains pale and limp and has no active respiratory effort. High-quality cardiopulmonary resuscitation is continued. Of the following the next best step of management is?
questions.solution:
• If a foreign body completely obstructs a child's upper airway and basic life support measures are unsuccessful, direct or video laryngoscopy should be performed.
  • Most aspirated foreign bodies in children lodge in the bronchial tree.
  • In patients with adequate airway patency, including partial upper- or lower-airway obstruction, the safest place for removal attempts is in the operating suite.
  • A child with an intact cough or cry will most likely dislodge a partially obstructing foreign body from the airway spontaneously.

Algorithm reference - Royal College of Health, Clinical guidelines - Inhaled Foreign Body

Topic: Foreign body aspiration

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number:541

questions.text: A 5-year-old was admitted to PICU for altered mental status and suspected meningitis. The child presents with generalized tonic clonic seizures since last 1 hour. You promptly administer benzodiazepines, fluids, and ceftriaxone and vacomycin. Despite anticonvulsants, the seizure persists. Which complication of meningitis is most likely to cause a seizure that is refractory to the above treatments?
questions.solution:
• Hyponatremia from the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of ADH (SIADH) is a common complication of bacterial meningitis.
  • Hyponatremic seizures are notoriously resistant to anticonvulsants and need to be treated with appropriate saline solutions.
  • A brain abscess (choice A) is a complication that may cause seizures, but usually is not one of the presenting signs. This complication may need neurosurgical care.
  • Again, subdural empyema (choice B) is not a presenting sign, but seizures resulting from irritation from an empyema usually respond well to therapy.
  • Increased ICP (choice D) is a possible complication from meningitis and may cause seizures (but not as common as hyponatremia).
  • Medical therapy is usually not sufficient.

Topic: Complicated meningitis

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA edition, page number: 2944

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy was referred by his GP following parental concerns about his behavior. He was described as aggressive at times and prone to temper tantrums. He would often leave things behind at school and then suggest that this was due to instructions from his teacher. His teachers described him as intelligent and although easily distracted, he could be absorbed in some of his work. He would deny following teacher's instructions. His mother acted as a single parent as his father was in prison for robbery. His growth is well in the age limits. What is the most likely explanation for his behavior?
questions.solution:
Oppositional defiant disorder

  • A pattern of angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, or vindictiveness lasting at least 6 months as evidenced by at least 4 symptoms from any of the following categories, and exhibited during interaction with at least 1 individual who is not a sibling.
    • Angry/Irritable Mood
      • Often loses temper.
      • Is often touchy or easily annoyed.
      • Is often angry and resentful.
    • Argumentative/Defiant Behavior
      • Often argues with authority figures or, for children and adolescents, with adults.
      • Often actively defies or refuses to comply with requests from authority figures or with rules.
      • Often deliberately annoys others.
      • Often blames others for his or her mistakes or misbehavior.
    • Vindictiveness
      • Has been spiteful or vindictive at least twice within the past 6 mo.;
  • The disturbance in behavior is associated with distress in the individual or others in his or her immediate social context (e.g., family, peer group, work colleagues), or it impacts negatively on social, educational, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
  • The behaviors do not occur exclusively during the course of a psychotic, substance use, depressive, or bipolar disorder. Also, the criteria are not met for disruptive mood dysregulation disorder.
  • Attention deficit disorder-although distractible he is able to concentrate on issues
  • Autism spectrum disorder-no repetitive or social awkward behaviors
  • Disruptive domestic circumstances-doesn't explain aggression and lying

Topic: Oppositional defiant disorder

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition., page number: 238

questions.text: A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is seen in the office for evaluation of bloody discharge from her left ear. She was seen earlier in the day by a general practitioner for ear pain. The urgent care provider could not visualize the left tympanic membrane because of the impacted wax. She used an ear curette to remove the cerumen and subsequently visualized a normal left tympanic membrane. After the visit, her mother noted blood coming from the left ear. The girl's vital signs are normal. Her physical examination findings are normal except for crusted blood in her left ear canal obscuring the tympanic membrane. Of the following the next best step is?
questions.solution:
• The child in the vignette should be given supportive care. Irrigation could further irritate the ear canal and exacerbate the bleeding. Antibiotic ear drops are not needed at this time because an infection has not been identified. Referral to an otolaryngologist is also unnecessary because she has a simple superficial irritation that will resolve.
  • Bloody otorrhea that results from superficial irritation of the ear canal requires only reassurance and supportive care.
  • Counseling patients on appropriate ear hygiene can prevent ear canal irritation.
  • Button batteries in the ear canal require emergent removal by an otolaryngologist.

Topic: Otitis media

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number:3435

choices.text: Arrange urgent CT scan of head

questions.text: A 3-year- old boy was brought to the emergency department by his father. He had been alone with his grandmother for the day and she had reported that he had not been 'his usual self' for about an hour. Over the following 2 hours at home, he became agitated and then increasingly drowsy. His father noted he had some jerking movements whilst being brought to hospital. On examination in hospital, his observations are pulse 124/minute, RR 24/minute and temp. 37.3 °C. His SpO2 is 98% with face mask oxygen. He has normal volume pulses, normal heart sounds and a capillary refill of <2 seconds. His chest is clear. Examination of the abdomen is normal. He opens his eyes to painful stimuli and has some abnormal flexion movements. He is only making mumbling sounds. What is the next most important response?
questions.solution:
• The clinical history is in keeping with a tricyclic overdose-drowsy, agitated, decreased GCS of 7 and a seizure. He also had time with an elderly relative who may not have appropriate safety measures around tablet storage. Priority is to protect airway.
  • Administer IV mannitol-clinical features do not suggest raised ICP
  • Arrange urgent CT scan of head-no suggestion of trauma or raised ICP
  • Collect urine for toxicology-important but not a priority.

Topic: TCA

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number:504

questions.text: An 8-year-old previously healthy girl presents to ER after a focal seizure with secondary generalization. She is afebrile. She returns to her baseline after brief observation. Her skin exam is normal. A head CT scan shows a contrast enhancing mass without surrounding edema or mass effect. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) are collections of abnormal blood vessels that connect arteries to veins without the intervening capillaries.
  • The imaging shows a typical contrast -enhancing tangled clump of vessels.
  • AVMs can hemorrhage, with clinical presentation of sudden headache, altered mental status, and possible focal neurologic deficits.
  • Glioblastoma multiforme is an aggressive tumor, and has a heterogeneous appearance, with surrounding edema and mass effect.

Image - Glioblastoma - A, Axial T2 weighted image shows a heterogeneous mass that is predominantly hypointense to cortex and relatively well circumscribed

  • A brain abscess has a different appearance at different stages of its evolution, but typically has ring enhancement.

  • A tram-track sign is a reflection of cortical calcifications due to leptomeningeal vascular malformations in Sturge-Weber syndrome.

Image - non-contrast brain CT scan, unilateral right-sided atrophy of cerebral hemisphere with gyriform cortico-subcortical (tram-track) calcification

Topic: AV malformation

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition., page number. 3462

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents to your clinic for evaluation of worsening gait instability and incoordination. His symptoms started shortly after he started walking as an infant and have been progressive. He is experiencing increasing difficulty with walking, and he sometimes trips and falls. His hands are shaky. He has had frequent sinus infections and pneumonias. Physical exam is remarkable for dysarthria, dysmetria on finger to nose, truncal ataxia, and ataxic gait. Dilated blood vessels are noted on the conjunctiva, auricles, and nasal bridge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Ataxia telangiectasia is characterized by progressive childhood onset ataxia, oculocutaneous telangiectasias, sinopulmonary infections, hematologic malignancies (leukemia and lymphoma), and radiosensitivity.
  • Patients are immunodeficient and have recurrent sinopulmonary infections requiring aggressive treatment.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder, and the causative gene is the ATM (ataxia telangiectasia mutated) gene, which is involved in DNA damage response and cell cycle regulation.
  • Alpha-fetoprotein is elevated in most patients.
  • Friedreich ataxia is also an autosomal recessive disorder presenting with gait ataxia. Symptoms typically begin around puberty (later than ataxia telangiectasia).
  • Loss of lower extremity deep tendon reflexes is typical. Other clinical features include diabetes and cardiomyopathy.

Topic: Ataxia telangiectasia

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number:1117

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right leg pain. Two days ago, he sustained a closed right distal tibia fracture after being hit by a car while riding his bicycle. He was evaluated at a local emergency department and underwent fracture reduction and cast placement under sedation. Initially, the boy required only occasional acetaminophen for pain. However, over the past 12 hours, he has had increasing pain. His parents have given him 2 doses of hydrocodone, but he has become increasingly difficult to console. On physical examination, the boy appears agitated. He has a cast on his right lower extremity. The boy is able to move his toes, which appear pink and well perfused. The remainder of his physical examination findings are normal. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Acute compartment syndrome occurs when increased pressure in the myofascial compartments leads to decreased blood flow and subsequent ischemia.
  • The "3 A's" (anxiety, agitation, and increased analgesic use) are useful indicators of the presence of acute compartment syndrome in children.
  • Children who have signs and symptoms of compartment syndrome require urgent orthopedic surgery consultation.

Topic: Compartment syndrome

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number: 3697

choices.text: Erythematous edematous and eroded gingival and buccal mucosa
Bilateral barely palpable painless subcutaneous nodules adjacent to olecranon process
Dermatomal linear streaks or plaques of upper or lower extremities
Hypertrophic, erythematous pinkish lesions overlying dorsal interphalangeal joints

questions.text: A 12-year-old female with a history of fever, weight loss, and arthralgia is noted on physical examination to have proximal muscle weakness. Laboratory findings include elevated levels of serum creatinine kinase, an elevated antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer, and a negative anti-double stranded DNA. Which of the following is most likely to be identified during physical examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient has clinical and laboratory manifestations of juvenile dermatomyositis. Hypertrophic, erythematous, pinkish lesions overlying the dorsal interphalangeal joints are known as Gottron papules and are considered a pathognomonic sign of the disorder.
  • Additional clinical manifestations may include:
    • Edematous, erythematous, bluish eyelids (heliotrope rash of the periorbital area)
    • Periorbital, cheek, and knee variegated telangiectasia
    • Periungual telangiectasia and cuticular hypertrophy
    • Dry, scaling scalp
    • Cutaneous calcinosis
  • Patients with juvenile dermatomyositis have proximal muscle weakness and may thus complain of difficulty brushing their teeth, combing their hair, climbing stairs, or standing from a sitting position.
  • Inflammatory changes may also affect the muscles of the gastrointestinal tract (causing constipation), the upper airway (causing dysphonia and dysphagia), and the heart (causing arrhythmias or cardiomyopathy).
  • Elevation of one or more muscle enzymes occurs in nearly every patient.
  • Patients usually have a normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and negative rumatoid factor (RF); up to 60% of patients with juvenile dermatomyositis have elevated ANA titers, whereas more specific tests for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), such as anti-double-stranded DNA, are negative.

Diagnostic criteria and clinical findings in Juvenile Dermatomyositis



Topic :Juvenile dermatomyositis

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number:1281-1282

questions.text: An 8-month-old child was brought to the emergency department with cough, fever, and breathlessness. Physical examination confirmed the diagnosis of pneumonia. The medical record of the child showed that this child had four attacks of pneumonia in the last four months. Given these and the family history, cystic fibrosis was suspected and sweat test was requested and showed a slightly raised chloride. Conditions other than cystic fibrosis might increase sweat chloride concentration and result in false positive results is?
questions.solution:
• Dehydration, by decreasing the effective renal blood flow, stimulates aldosterone secretion. As in the renal tubules, aldosterone would stimulate reabsorption of sodium and chloride by the ducts of sweat glands. A false negative, rather than false positive result is expected with dehydration.
  • Hypovolemia has an effect similar to dehydration.
  • Steroids, even if they are of the glucocorticoid type like cortisol would some mineralocorticoid activity. A false negative rather than false positive is expected.
  • Although measurement of sweat chloride level is probably the most useful test in diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, false positive test result is possible. The collection process of sweat should thus, be standardized and the hemodynamic stability of the patient optimized before sweat collection.

  • Some additional points for sweat test
  • Positive newborn screen for cystic fibrosis - perform sweat test after 36-wk corrected gestational age and at a weight greater than 2 kg and at age greater than 10 days
  • Electric current and pilocarpine used to produce sweat from sweat glands
  • Performed on volar aspect

Topic :Sweat chloride test

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition., page number: 2288

questions.text: While at school, a 6-year-old boy is noted by his teacher to experience 10- to 20-second lapses in consciousness, sometimes with clonic movements of the face. His parents have not noticed this behavior at home. Electroencephalography shows 3 per second generalized spike and wave discharges. The MOST appropriate therapy for this boy is:
questions.solution:
History and EEG findings (3 per second generalized spike and wave discharges) point towards Absence seizures.

  • Absence seizures are characterized by a brief loss and return of consciousness, generally not followed by a period of lethargy (i.e., without a notable postictal state).

Treatment of Absence seizure:

  • Initially treated with ethosuximide
  • Alternative drugs of first choice are lamotrigine and valproate (especially if generalized tonic-clonic seizures coexist with absence seizures)

Topic: Absence seizure

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number: 3096, 3103-3104

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy has a chronic cough. His mother notes that he coughs at night several times each week, enough to wake her but it does not seem to bother him. He has trouble keeping up with peers in sports activities and gym class; he says he runs out of breath easily and has to stop and rest. There is a family history of asthma in a paternal uncle, cystic fibrosis in a maternal cousin, and seasonal allergies in both parents. Physical examination findings are normal, including growth parameters and vital signs. Of the following the best next step in his evaluation is?
questions.solution:
• Spirometry provides objective information about airway obstruction that may be missed from history or physical examination alone.
  • If there is sign of airway obstruction on spirometry, repeating spirometry 15 to 20 minutes after administration of inhaled bronchodilator could establish reversible airflow obstruction, indicating the diagnosis of asthma.

Topic: Chronic cough

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number: 2158
